Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Realizing the Untapped Potential of Multielectron Insertion/Extraction Reactions in Lithium Ion Batteries
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer Research (STTR) project is the commercialization of a high-capacity energy storage material with potential impact for electrified vehicles, grid-level energy storage, and portable electronic devices. Increased electric vehicle range and grid-level energy storage capacity would lead to greater market penetration of electrified vehicles, renewable energy sources, and batteries, with environmental benefits.

This Small Business Technology Transfer Research (STTR) Phase I project aims to develop a lithium ion intercalation cathode that can reversibly access more than one lithium ion per reduction-oxidation center, boosting energy storage capacity substantially. The problem is that after nearly a decade commercially available lithium ions batteries such as the commercially dominant lithium cobalt oxide and its derivatives are still limited to just one lithium per redox center, which establishes an immutable constraint on performance. In fact, these materials likely represent the ultimate limit for intercalation reactions involving just one lithium. The recently discovered zeta-V2O5 polymorph demonstrates the reversible intercalation of multiple lithium ions per vanadium redox center reaching remarkable capacities without a loss in capacity due to poor structure stability. In fact, zeta-V2O5 demonstrates near zero expansion/contraction during charging and discharging. This project will focus on (1) a high throughput screening of compositional space with the aim of increasing the nominal voltage, (2) iterative coin cell fabrication and characterization to correlate composition to performance, and (3) post-mortem analysis of cell failure. Lithium ion zeta-V2O5 based battery prototypes will demonstrate the highly reversible accessibility of vanadium 5+/4+ and 4+/3+ redox couples, approaching the 440 mAh/g theoretical capacity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Small Business Technology Transfer phase I project sought to innovate, develop, and validate the synthesis and electrochemical performance of a newly discovered vanadium-based cathode as a potential replacement to today's rechargeable battery cathodes. Batteries are an energy storage device that captures and stores energy in the form of a chemical reaction. They contain a positive terminal (cathode), negative terminal (anode), separator, and electrolyte. During discharge, lithium ions migrate in the electrolyte from the anode through the separator to the cathode. This causes electrons to flow through a corresponding circuit powering a device. Every lithium that is shuttled from the anode and inserted (intercalated) into the cathode has to have a parking spot. Scientifically this parking spot is called a reduction-oxidation site or redox site for short. The 2019 Nobel Prize in Chemistry was awarded to M. Stanley Whittingham, John B. Goodenough, and Akira Yoshino for their foundational scientific research that resulted in the rechargeable battery world we live in today. Batteries provide energy mobility in numerous ways such as cell phones, power tools, hearing aids, wearable devices, and electric vehicles, to name a few. The goal of this project was to safely and economically shuttle as many lithium ions as possible between suitable redox sites in the anode and cathode in the smallest possible mass and volume with our newly discovered vanadium-based cathode, called ζ-V2O5.

We achieved a 330 mAh/g battery cathode at C/20 discharge rate. The cathode demonstrated fast charge and discharge capability at 5C while maintaining 170 mAh/g within a 2.0-4.0 V window. After 500 cycles at 5C the battery maintains 80% of the 5C starting capacity. Upon slow cycling at C/5 and subsequently C/20 after the 500 cycles at 5C, that cathode recovers to more than 95% of its starting capacity.

Multi-beam optical stress measurements demonstrated that mechanical stress build-up within the composite cathodes was minimal. Furthermore, single-crystal diffraction characterization of the lattice as lithium ions intercalated into ζ-V2O5 showed a less than 5% change in unit cell size, even up to two lithium ions per redox site. Given the micro-crack capacity limitation of nickel rich cathodes that is derived from large unit cell volume changes, minimal stress buildup and small volume changes during lithium cycling in next generation cathodes is a critical milestone for commercialization. Through this same work, we mapped the diffusion pathway of lithium ions as they traversed through the cathode structure. Our methods enabled atomistic imaging of lithium ions in a cathode where the state-of-the-art has thus far relied on computational models and/or imaging at large length scales. Dimien's vanadium-based, high capacity, highly cyclable replacement to rechargeable single-electron intercalation batteries unlocks two and three electron capability by nearly eliminating electrochemical stress. Acting on the same intercalation mechanism, which shuttles lithium ions to and from the positive and negative terminals of a battery, our vanadium-based multi-electron intercalation batteries provide greater gravimetric and volumetric energy density at lower cost. Next steps are aimed at investigating larger format cells with optimized battery materials and components to eliminate potential future roadblocks to commercialization.
